abstract.p: Howard Goldberg reviews Carmel's emerald reisling and chenin blanc blend; photo (M)

block.p: An Israeli hedonist's vision of heaven is Carmel's emerald riesling and chenin blanc blend, lightly cool, alternating with forkfuls of grilled sweet-fleshed St. Peter's fish at a restaurant on the Sea of Galilee.

An Israeli hedonist's vision of heaven is Carmel's emerald riesling and chenin blanc blend, lightly cool, alternating with forkfuls of grilled sweet-fleshed St. Peter's fish at a restaurant on the Sea of Galilee.

This tangy, weightless, semidry white, a best-selling starlet at home, enchants Americans and not only Jews. Kosher? Certainly. No less important, the wine expresses hip international technical and aesthetic standards.

Its perfumed confectionery bouquet and spicy tropical-compote flavors, highlighted by a gewurztraminer-like litchi spin and eddies of grapefruit-rind candy, can give a casual dinner party a festive air.

Israel is a diaspora for emerald riesling, which is not a true riesling but a marriage, arranged at the University of California at Davis in the 1940's, of German riesling -- the Schiller of European white-wine grapes -- and muscadelle, a supporting actor in Bordeaux. Chenin blanc prospers in the Loire.

Baron Edmond de Rothschild founded Carmel in 1882 in Palestine. Jolted by competition, Carmel in recent years has spent millions to upgrade its farming and cellar in hopes of recovering a slice of a long-taken-for-granted Goliath-size market share at home and abroad.

In Manhattan, the blend costs $7 at at 86th Street Wines, 306 East 86th (Second Avenue), and McCabe's, 1347 Third Avenue (77th Street); in Brooklyn, $8 at Orlander's, 1781 Ocean Avenue (Avenue M), and $9.25 at A Touch of Spirit, 4720 16th Avenue (48th Street), Borough Park.
